1582105711_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body: dd is like the most foolproof way of doing it assuming you get the size correctly and your drives are healthy. ddrescue is a better approach if your drives show faults. But dd is slow in respect that it just copies empty space as well. Using more specialized tools like partclone and ntfsclone (for ntfs partitions) allows to skip most free space, and if you use Clonezilla you could even clone to an smaller drive given there's enough free space to lay data out in the destination drive. Though, partclone doesn't produce exact clones so it may not be what you are after if trying to duplicate licensed software or other things. Even UUIDs may end up changing at the end.

1601197833_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
Just a note, you can do just that with ddrescue alone, once it recovers what it can from the faulty drive it will have left the bad sectors marked with a '-' symbol in its mapfile, you can then use fill mode on it like this:
    `ddrescue -f -F '-' /dev/zero /dev/sdX mapfile`
and it will overwrite with zeros from /dev/zero the bad sectors in /dev/sdX as per the mapfile. I prefer it this way as I don't have to bother too much about proper sector sizes/addresses when writing over bad blocks, which in your case you may not be paying too much attention; your dd command is using bs=1024 which sets the input block size (the one that seek uses) to 1024bytes as well, that is, you will be seeking to the sectors listed by badblocks but that is assuming your disk (or badblocks, which actually does) uses 1 kilobyte sectors instead of conventional 512 bytes sectors or modern 4096 sectors. I think it would be better to make badblocks use 512byte sectors in its listing so if you forget to put 'bs=1024' in dd it will still work as dd's default block size is still 512bytes.
